title: 111_s3238
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that the tragic events of September 11, 2001, have forever changed the nation. The heroic actions of officers, emergency workers, and employees who responded to the attacks at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon are recognized. The passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 are also acknowledged for their bravery in preventing further casualties. The heroic actions of individuals aboard aircraft on September 11, 2001, prevented further tragedy and should be recognized with an appropriate medal. SEC. 3. FALLEN HEROES OF 9/11 CONGRESSIONAL MEDALS. The President is authorized to award a "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals and organizations in recognition of their sacrifices and to honor those who died on and after September 11, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs of medals for this purpose. The Secretary will determine the design of the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to honor those who lost their lives in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center, Pentagon, and Flight 93. Consultation with the Secretary of Defense and other relevant parties will precede the final design decision. The medals will be silver and struck for this purpose. The medals authorized by subsection (a) will be silver for honoring individuals who died as a direct result of the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Eligibility for the medal will be determined by the Secretary in consultation with other government officials. SEC. 4. DUPLICATE MEDALS.

The Secretary will create bronze duplicates of the medals for distribution to precinct houses, firehouses, and other duty stations where individuals who responded to the 9/11 attacks were assigned. These duplicates will be displayed in memory of the individuals who perished.

SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF LISTS OF RECIPIENTS. Before the end of the 120-day period after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will establish lists of eligible individuals to receive a medal under section 3(c)(1) and eligible recipients of a duplicate medal under section 4. Consultation with various organizations will be done to make determinations, and the lists established will be final. The Secretary will establish lists of eligible individuals and recipients for medals under sections 3(c)(1) and 4. The determinations made are final and not subject to judicial review. If anyone becomes eligible, their name will be promptly added to the appropriate list. SEC. 6. The Secretary can sell duplicate bronze medals to cover costs. SEC. 7. Medals are considered national medals under the law.
